newsitem.title: GREECE: Greece launches world's biggest solar power plant.
newsitem.headline: Greece launches world's biggest solar power plant.

text.p: Greece announced on Thursday plans to build the world's biggest solar power plant on the holiday island of Crete.

"The Greek government backs investments involving alternative energy sources and that's why it decided to support the construction of the world's biggest photovoltaic power station on Crete," Development Minister Vasso Papandreou told a news conference.

The environmental group Greenpeace, which has campaigned for years to turn Crete into a solar-powered island, said in a statement the project would shatter assumptions that solar power needs expensive investments.
Greece and the European Union will fund 55 percent of the $17.75 million needed to build the first five megawatt of the proposed 50 megawatt station, it said.
IWECO Solar, a subsidiary of the U.S. Enron Solar company, will build and operate the plant. Its proposal calls for building nine megawatts a year to reach 50 megawatts by 2003.

"At 50 megawatts, the Crete solar power station would be 15 times larger than any other solar photovolatic installation in the world," Greenpeace said. Italy now has the world's biggest solar power plant at 3.3 megawatts.
The station is designed to cover the energy needs of 100,000 people at a price lower than that charged by Greece's Public Power Corporation.
"This smashes conventional assumptions on solar power in terms of scale and costs," said Greenpeace International Executive Director, Thilo Bode, in Athens to celebrate the announcement of the plant.
"If the world builds the equivalent of eight such solar power stations, we can create a $27 billion market for solar photovoltaic and create hundreds of thousands of jobs," he said.
Bode urged governments to invest in environmentally friendly energy sources in order to reduce pollutants, such as carbon dioxide, which are blamed for altering the earth's climate.
Greenpeace wants nations to commit to a 20 percent reduction of carbon dioxide by 2005 and to begin negotiations for a fossil fuel phaseout, including a halt to new oil exploration.
"This is the type of energy investment which governments must now implement if we are to have a chance of avoiding dangerous climate change," Bode said.
